questions.text: A 36-year-old woman was involved in a car accident two months ago, and she now complains of screaming and waking up in the middle of the night after having nightmares about the same incident over and over. Which of the following conditions does she have? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Post traumatic stress disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PTSD manifests after experiencing or witnessing significant traumatic event , with symptoms like flashbacks, nightmares,hypervigilance, exaggerated startle response, severe anxiety centered on the event and avoidance of the situations that remind of the trauma. The symptoms must be present for at least one month . It is more common in females and young adults. Hippocampus and amygdala are implicated in the etiology of PTSD. Treatment includes trauma-focussed CBT (treatment of choice), SSRIs (Drug of choice), and eye movements desensitization and reprocessing.
  • ➤ significant traumatic event
  • ➤ one month
  • ➤ Hippocampus
  • ➤ amygdala
  • ➤ trauma-focussed CBT
  • ➤ SSRIs

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 439-441.

questions.text: You are attending physiology viva. The examiner asks you who recorded the first EEG. You say "I don't know "The examiner feels bad for you and gives you a clue that "the name sounds like something you get commonly in McDonalds". You remember the name and answer correctly. What type of memory has been implicated here?" (INICET May 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Priming

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Priming means that a recent experience makes it easier for you to notice or identify something related.
  • ➤ Perceptual Priming: Recognizing something becomes easier because you've recently seen something that looks similar. For example, if you've just seen a picture of a lion, you'll be faster at spotting the word "lion" even if it's a bit unclear.
  • ➤ Conceptual Priming: Understanding or noticing something becomes easier because you've recently thought about a related idea. For example, if you've just read about rivers and banks, you'll probably guess the word "bank" when given "ban_" instead of thinking of "band."

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 116.

questions.text: A woman, who is 5 days postpartum, presented with tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)

Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks. Mainstay of management is reassurance, support, and education.

questions.text: A person missing from home is found wandering purposefully. He is well-groomed and denies having any amnesia. Most likely diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dissociative Fugue

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Dissociative fugue is characterized by sudden, unexpected travel away from one's home or usual place of activities, with the inability to recall some or all of one's past. Individuals in a fugue state may adopt a new identity and appear well-groomed and purposeful. They often have no awareness of their amnesia during the fugue state, which aligns with the presentation described in the question.
  • • Comparison Table for Dissociative Fugue and Dissociative Amnesia
  • • Comparison Table for Dissociative Fugue and Dissociative Amnesia
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Dissociative Amnesia : Characterized by patchy memory loss without purposeful wandering or adopting a new identity. Patients are often aware of their memory gaps.
  • • Option B. Dissociative Amnesia :
  • • Option C. Schizophrenia : A mental disorder characterized by delusions, hallucinations, disorganized thinking, and impaired functioning. Not typically associated with purposeful wandering and adopting a new identity.
  • • Option C. Schizophrenia :
  • • Option D. Dementia : A decline in cognitive function, often with memory loss, but typically progresses over time and includes other cognitive impairments. Patients may wander but usually show signs of cognitive decline and confusion.
  • • Option D. Dementia :

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dissociative fugue involves sudden, unexpected travel away from home with the adoption of a new identity and lack of awareness of amnesia during the fugue state.

questions.text: During TURP, the surgeon takes care to dissect above the verumontanum to prevent injury to: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) External urethral sphincter

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The verumontanum, also known as the seminal colliculus, is an important anatomical landmark during Transurethral Resection of the Prostate (TURP). It is crucial for the surgeon to avoid dissecting below this landmark to prevent damage to the external urethral sphincter, which lies just distal to the verumontanum. Injury to this sphincter can lead to complications such as urinary incontinence.
  • • Key Anatomical Landmark in TURP:
  • • Key Anatomical Landmark in TURP:
  • • The verumontanum serves as a critical stopping point for resection during TURP to avoid the external urethral sphincter and reduce the risk of post-operative complications related to urinary continence.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Urethral crest: The urethral crest is located within the prostatic urethra but is not as critical in the context of avoiding injury during TURP.
  • • Option B. Urethral crest:
  • • Option C. Prostatic utricle: The prostatic utricle is a small indentation in the prostatic urethra, but its injury is less consequential than that of the external urethral sphincter.
  • • Option C. Prostatic utricle:
  • • Option D. Trigone of the bladder: The trigone of the bladder is located within the bladder itself and is not relevant to the TURP procedure.
  • • Option D. Trigone of the bladder:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During TURP, dissection above the verumontanum is crucial to prevent injury to the external urethral sphincter.

questions.text: A persistent alcoholic patient presents with convulsions and impaired sensorium. He has been drinking for ten years and consumes 24 units every day. His most recent drink was two days ago. He is discovered to have auditory hallucinations as well as secondary delusions. What method will you employ to manage this patient? Diazepam Thiamine Naltrexone Flupenthixol depot injection
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 472-473.

SSRIs & MAO-Is have shown efficacy in treating atypical depression, making them a potential therapeutic option for this subtype.

questions.text: Which of the following is more common in Anorexia Nervosa when compared to Bulimia Nervosa? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Amenorrhea is more frequently associated with anorexia nervosa, primarily due to the effects of significant caloric restriction and weight loss on the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. Starvation leads to a drop in GnRH, which lowers FSH and LH levels, resulting in decreased estrogen and subsequent menstrual irregularities or absence. While amenorrhea was once a diagnostic criterion in DSM-IV and ICD-10, it is no longer required in DSM-5 or ICD-11—but it remains a common clinical feature.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Dental Caries : More common in bulimia nervosa due to frequent self-induced vomiting. The repeated exposure of teeth to stomach acid leads to enamel erosion and caries—less typical in the restricting subtype of anorexia . Option B. Antisocial Behavior: Neither disorder is primarily associated with antisocial traits. However, bulimia nervosa has stronger links to impulsivity and emotion dysregulation. In contrast, anorexia nervosa is often marked by control, rigidity, and perfectionism. Option C. Craving for Food: Intense food cravings, particularly those leading to binge eating, are more characteristic of bulimia nervosa. While people with anorexia may think obsessively about food, they usually resist these urges rather than act on them.
  • • Option A. Dental Caries : More common in bulimia nervosa due to frequent self-induced vomiting. The repeated exposure of teeth to stomach acid leads to enamel erosion and caries—less typical in the restricting subtype of anorexia .
  • • Option A. Dental Caries
  • • .
  • • Option B. Antisocial Behavior: Neither disorder is primarily associated with antisocial traits. However, bulimia nervosa has stronger links to impulsivity and emotion dysregulation. In contrast, anorexia nervosa is often marked by control, rigidity, and perfectionism.
  • • Option B. Antisocial Behavior:
  • • Option C. Craving for Food: Intense food cravings, particularly those leading to binge eating, are more characteristic of bulimia nervosa. While people with anorexia may think obsessively about food, they usually resist these urges rather than act on them.
  • • Option C. Craving for Food:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amenorrhea is a hallmark physiological consequence of the nutritional and hormonal imbalances seen in anorexia nervosa. Recognizing this and other subtle distinctions between anorexia and bulimia can help guide both diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A patient has the freedom to pick his or her caretaker and future course of action in treatment under the Mental Health Care Act of 2017. What is the name of this provision? (AIIMS MAY 2019)

questions.text: After abstaining from alcohol for three days, a patient presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. In this case, what is the most likely diagnosis? ( NEET PG 2021)

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has intense food cravings. She consumes a large amount of food, followed by self-induced vomiting. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)

Weight is usually normal, which differentiates from anorexia nervosa. Treatment includes CBT and SSRIs.

questions.text: All of the following are disorders of perception, except: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Delusion

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Delusion is typically classified as a disorder of thought rather than a disorder of perception. It involves holding false beliefs that are not based on reality and are resistant to reason or confrontation with actual facts. Delusions can be seen in various psychiatric conditions, such as schizophrenia, but they do not involve the misinterpretation or false perception of sensory stimuli, which characterizes disorders of perception.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Illusion : This is a misinterpretation of a real external stimulus, such as seeing a shadow and thinking it is a person.
  • • Option A. Illusion
  • • Option B. Hallucination : This is a perception that occurs without any external stimulus, such as hearing voices that are not there.
  • • Option B. Hallucination
  • • Option D. Depersonalization : This involves a feeling of detachment from one’s own body or thoughts, as if one is observing oneself from outside.
  • • Option D. Depersonalization

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Delusion is a disorder of thought, not a disorder of perception.

questions.text: A known alcoholic patient is brought to the emergency in a disoriented state. He complains of seeing snakes and insects crawling on his skin. Which of the following should be given to this patient? ( INICET May 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lorazepam + thiamine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient is displaying signs of alcohol withdrawal, particularly delirium tremens (DTs) which is characterized by confusion, visual and tactile hallucinations (like seeing snakes and feeling bugs crawling on the skin), tremors, and autonomic hyperactivity.
  • • Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine and is the treatment of choice for alcohol withdrawal, including DTs. Thiamine is essential to administer before or alongside glucose administration to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy in alcohol-dependent individuals. Haloperidol may be used to control severe agitation or hallucinations but is not a first-line therapy for DTs and could lower the seizure threshold.
  • • Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine and is the treatment of choice for alcohol withdrawal, including DTs.
  • • Thiamine is essential to administer before or alongside glucose administration to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy in alcohol-dependent individuals.
  • • Haloperidol may be used to control severe agitation or hallucinations but is not a first-line therapy for DTs and could lower the seizure threshold.
  • • Haloperidol may be used to control severe agitation or hallucinations but is not a first-line therapy for DTs and could lower the seizure threshold.

Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with schizophrenia was started on risperidone. After taking the medication last night, the patient rushes to OPD today with complaints of upwards rolling of his eyes. What is the management of the condition? ( INICET May 2022)

It usually occurs within hours of starting antipsychotic medication. They can be distressing but are reversible. Anticholinergic agents like promethazine (IM or IV) are first-line treatments for these reactions .
